+MegaGideo I hate the word 'crony capitalism' or 'corporatism', as if to 
say there's actually a difference. The entire point of capitalism is to 
make billions from doing absolutely nothing by privately owning the means 
of production through control of state violence, thereby inherently 
creating a class of people that have no other choice but to work for you. 
As long as the state exists, those that own capital will always be driven 
by their need for competitive advantage to exploit and corrupt the system. 
As for the point about capitalism being the innovator that got mankind out 
of the mire, I think I can partially agree, simply because I don't think 
it's the only factor, I think imperialism arguably played a bigger role. 
However, technology's reached a point where capitalism is not only 
unnecessary, but deadly. There is absolute no reason why 1% of the 
population should have exclusive access to 40% of the planet's resources, 
that's insane.

being to create energy or matter. Gravity pulls at 9.8 m/s/s because of the 
mass of the Earth creating a well in the field of gravity. The universe is 
abundant with lighter elements such as hydrogen (over 90% of the universe' 
atoms) which is consistent with the release of protons and electrons from 
the big bang. The amount of microwave radiation in the universe is also 
greater than it would be without the big bang. The movement of the galaxies 
from each other has been an inconsistent pace that has slowed and sped up 
at certain junctions and is still accelerating. The Bible also indicates 
that Heaven itself is hotter than Hell and that Jesus cried out in anguish 
blaming God as he was being crucified.

comments.text:
I would like to see the scientific studies you've found that disprove God 
beyond a shadow of a doubt. I will give them a read if you give this a read.

Science can most definitely observe how the Creator works in our world. 
Science uses the fact that our laws of physics and how the world operates 
is unchanging. This is a God-driven principle that God is faithful and 
never changing, He will always make gravity fall at a rate of 9.8m/s and 
make the sun rise.

But can it tell me where gravity comes from? Where does instinct come from? 
How do the birds know which direction to go according to the stars? How can 
they swoop down at super fast speeds and pick up food without smashing on 
the ground successfully? What drives these forces? Simply put, science can 
observe but it falls short of giving us answers to WHY.

So, point #2 I'd like to point out. The universe is ever-expanding. It's 
been expanding at a steady rate, which is why people think that proves 
there was a big bang and there will be an expanding and eventually a 
contracting (probably billions of years after we die supposedly).

I'm not going to go into the big bang but what I will tell you is this: in 
1929, Edwin Hubble discovered that the universe was expanding. This was a 
huge discovery! Now we humans could grasp the fact that the galaxies are 
stretched like a garment. (Source: 
http://cosmology.carnegiescience.edu/timeline/1929)

But... There's writers who lived thousands of years before we humans could 
observe this fact. (you can agree the bible is an ancient manuscript, 
correct?)
"He alone stretches out the heavens" Job 9:8
"The LORD wraps himself in light as with a garment; he stretches out the 
heavens like a tent." Psalm 104:2
And many more! If you want to read the list I pulled this from: 
http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/nave-html/faithpathh/stretch.html)

Before Humans had the technology to observe the stars and the workings of 
the universe, we were told by God how He works! He stretches the heavens 
and the bible declares this thousands of years before we could observe this 
for ourselves.
comments.author: Francisco Gonzalez

comments.text:
+Chris Lucas Since 2005, China has been becoming steadily better overall. 
Animal cruelty laws are more respected there now than they were a few years 
ago. In fact, until around 2005, the only way to run for office, even at 
the lowest level, was to be a member of the Communist party. However, now, 
you can even be a candidate against the party and still run for lower level 
offices, such as mayor. The amount of executions in China is also 
decreasing. Back in the 1990's, China executed around 25,000 people a year 
on average. By 2005, it had decreased to around 10,000. Today, the annual 
amount of executions is around 2,000. The amount of executions in China has 
been falling by around 10% every year for the last several years. In 2006, 
China even made a law that says that all death sentences have to go before 
the Supreme Court, and nearly 20% of death sentences that go to the Supreme 
Court are commuted.

Interestingly, China stopped executing juveniles nearly a decade before the 
USA did. China stopped executing juveniles around 1997, while the USA only 
stopped executing juveniles in 2004. However, I doubt that China will ever 
become "Western" in the way we perceive the definition. China, in about 
15-20 years, might become "Western" in the sense that some people consider 
countries like South Korea, Japan and the Philippines to be Western, but I 
doubt that China will ever get any closer than that. 

Apparently, a few years ago, the Chinese government has even started a 
programme to end homelessness. Their solution is to give a sort of stipend 
for low level individuals and families, and give them small apartments to 
live in. Right now, there are millions who live in slum neighbourhoods, but 
the government is working on a solution for it. Remember too, there are now 
Millennium generation Chinese joining the government, who tend to have a 
more moderate view on society. They will also likely have an influence on 
changing the government in China. And while about 75-80% of older Chinese 
still favours the death penalty in China, most younger Chinese are either 
against it altogether, or think that it should be used less frequently.

comments.text:
+Joseph F No, your "evidence" is an ideological belief that rich people are 
generous because they give money to charity, even though the amount they

Because people don't "vote for government welfare programs." Do you even

What about a free market doesn't allow slavery or forced labor? You need to

You know, I'm actually bothering to read the occasional reference you send

"First you must establish that we have the right to do something before you 
can argue whether or not we need to do it, or if it's a good idea."
Uh, no, I don't. It's assumed that a nation has a right to govern itself in 
some way, obviously. If you want to get into a theoretical and 
philosophical discussion about what gives us the right to make decisions, 
that's your business, but as far as I'm concerned that's silly and has no 
real world application; not unlike the rest of your ideas, frankly.
I don't think absolutely any deforestation is wrong; I think unnecessary 
deforestation in the interest of personal profit, especially by people who 
are already wealthy, is wrong. And the fact that sometimes people who own

comments.author: americanslime

comments.text:
+americanslime
I'm not just assuming that people would give money to charities if there 
was no welfare. I provided evidence for that claim. I'm also not just 
assuming that the recipients of charities would benefit more than the 
recipients of welfare. I provided evidence for that claim too. You can't 
accuse me of just assuming things that I've provided evidence for. That 
isn't being very honest.

Maybe people wouldn't research charities very well before donating to them, 
but then why would you assume that they'd research government welfare 
programs before voting for them? You can't have it both ways. Either people 
will research charities, in which case there's no reason why charity can't 
be a reliable solution, or they won't, in which case they won't research 
government welfare programs either.

Who is kidnapped? I'm not sure who you're referring to. If you mean the 
diamond miners, it's not a free market situation if they're being 
kidnapped. So I'm not sure what that has to do with anything that I'm 
advocating.

I never advocated child labor. I don't think it should be illegal for 
children to work, but I'm not saying whether they should or shouldn't. That 
depends on what they want to do and the particular circumstances involved.

"Because it's necessary" does not answer my question. First you must 
establish that we have the right to do something before you can argue 
whether or not we need to do it, or if it's a good idea. Telling me that we 
need to do something doesn't explain what gives us the right to do it, 
unless you're saying that we have the right to do anything that we need to 
do. If that's the case, who gets to decide what we need to do? The 
majority? What about when the majority decided that we needed to have 
slaves? Did that make it right?

If you're claiming that any deforestation is wrong, you're going to have to 
make the case for that. Also, most government property is the product of 
deforestation as well; so, again, I don't see how the government offers an 
alternative.

If you're not claiming that any deforestation is bad, but you are instead 
claiming that all privatization of land results in deforestation, your 
claim is demonstrably false. We have examples of privately owned land where 
forests are preserved. Since there's way more land than we actually need 
for living on or building communities on, it's hard to imagine why anyone 
would spend the money to chop down all the trees covering the land that we 
don't use. It seems like that would just be a tremendous waste of their own 
resources, and they'd gain nothing from it.

If you're not claiming either of those things, I have no idea what you're 
claiming.

When a government gives a contract to a private business, no other 
businesses are allowed to compete with that business. I can't open my own 
competing prison down the street.

Actually, I've never heard any definition of a government that could exist 
in a truly free market. Governments are inherently the opposite of free 
markets. You could have a mostly free market with a small government that 
only did certain things, but whatever aspects of the market that were 
affected by the government would not be free. So, in your example of a 
government contracting a private prison, that prison would not be part of 
the free market.

Are you honestly asking me why government enforced slavery isn't a product 
of the free market? Now you're just being ridiculous. Anything that is 
funded through taxation is not a product of the free market. This is 
especially the case when the thing that's being funded is the ownership of 
other human beings.

Anything that's funded through taxation has nothing to do with the free 
market. If the government forces people to fund something through their 
taxes, then the government is controlling the demand. This isn't rocket 
science.
comments.author: Joseph F

comments.text:
+Joseph F So now you're not only assuming most wealthy people would give 
large portions of their income to charity in lieu of taxes, and that the 
supposedly increased revenue would make up for all the people who would 
give nothing or less than their fair share, you're also assuming all these 
people would carefully research the charity they give money to? I don't 
know what to say, except that you are one seriously optimistic dude.

No, they're kidnapped. I knew you had some strange ideas, but I'm honestly 
stunned. You're actually advocating child labor?

Because it's necessary, of course. Governments are essential to organize 
and provide for enormous populations, and thus have to make decisions an 
individual cannot make. An individual shouldn't be allowed to lock a person 
he's convinced is a murderer in his basement, but that doesn't mean we 
shouldn't have prisons or a justice system. Like it or not, SOMEONE has to 
decide what to do in the event of war, or natural disaster, or food 
distribution. It stands to reason that the most equitable and rational way 
to do this is to give the people as much choice as possible by having 
decisions made by their democratically elected representatives.

Now, back to your earlier points:
"People tend to take much better care of private property than they do of 
unowned property or public property. The way to best protect and preserve 
the environment would be to privatize as much land as possible."
Well, we live in a highly privatized landscape and deforestation is 
abundant and constant. The reasons are obvious. They don't "take better 
care of it", they develop it to make money. Literally the real estate term 
for wilderness is "unimproved land". I live right near a floodplain forest 
of centuries old silver maple which citizens are currently trying to keep 
its owner from destroying to build an apartment complex. 
First Nations did not regard their land as private property beyond it being 
owned by the tribe, and they managed to form an immensely beneficial 
symbiotic relationship with the wilderness. The only surviving forests of 
significant size in my area are reservations maintained by the towns and 
cities that contain them. What you're saying is completely contradictory to 
everything we know about capitalism and the environment. Please, show me 
some evidence that privatizing wilderness supports it.

How does the government "enforce" private prison monopolies? The prison is 
selling a product, the government is purchasing it. A free market is one 
wherein the government is not controlling the supply and demand. That 
doesn't mean a government can't exist or buy services. And the inmates are 
working at slave wages for the profit of the prison itself because there is 
no- say it with me- regulation to stop them. In your model the prison 
should be making money by making the inmates' lives better, yet they're 
making money through exploitation. Why? Because it's easier to make money 
through exploitation, of course.

By the same token, how does a government retrieving what was legally 
regarded as lost property anti-free market? The slave trade existed with 
the intent of making money, and claimed human beings as a commodity. There 
is nothing anti-free market about that either.

And again, what about a free market necessitates the government doesn't buy 
anything with tax dollars? You seem to have your own definition of what a 
free market is wherein it's only a free market if the government not only 
puts no regulation on it, but doesn't even interact with it or handle money 
whatsoever.
comments.author: americanslime

comments.text:
+americanslime
The great thing about giving to charity is that you get to pick which 
charities you give to. If there are certain charities where less than 70% 
of the money goes to the people who need it, or where you have no way of 
knowing how much of it goes to the people who need it, you don't have to 
give to those charities. You can just give to the ones that you know give 
70% to those who need it. Same goes for charities spending money on 
different things. You would be free to give to the charities that spent 
money on what you believed was important, and not give to the ones that you 
felt were not important. So I don't see why this is a problem. It seems 
like you're just nitpicking.

In a free market, why would a person take a job as a diamond miner if they 
were better off by not taking the job? Are they just masochistic?

And please answer my question about how we're able to delegate rights that 
we don't have to the government. I deliberately put that question at the 
beginning of my last post because it's the #1 thing that I would like for 
you to answer.

comments.text:
+Joseph F "Your implication that none of the people who are against welfare 
want to help the poor is demonstrably false"
That's not my implication. My implication is that many, many wouldn't, as 
I've already indicated from actual data.
"About 70% of the money that goes into private charities gets to the people 
who need it, where as only about 30% of the money that goes into government 
welfare programs gets to the people who need it."
Your source used numbers derived from charitynavigator.org claiming that of 
all the charities that website covers, an average of 70% of the money given 
to them is used. Now, there are a few problems with that. From their 
website: "We do not evaluate charities that are exempt from filing the Form 
990. Many religious organizations, like the Salvation Army, are exempt 
under Internal Revenue Code from filing the Form 990. As a result, we lack 
sufficient data to evaluate their financial health." Also, different 
charities are managed in different ways. Your local church will not spend 
its money the same way as, say, the Kids Wish Network. Generally local 
churches are going to spend their money much more efficiently than a big 
foundation, because they are asking for donations expressly to spend on 
themselves. I'm not saying you're necessarily wrong, but the parameters of 
that study are far too broad to be read so simplistically.
No, diamond miners are not better off because they have a job. Read up: 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Child_labour_in_the_diamond_industry I'll 
respond to the rest of this later.

comments.author: americanslime

comments.text:
+americanslime
In regard to my question about how we can delegate rights that we don't 
have, I'm not going anywhere. I would sincerely like an answer. We can't 
delegate rights that we don't have in any other situation. For example, I 
don't have the right to sell your house. So I can't hire my brother to sell 
your house for me. How is it that this changes when it comes to the 
government, and we suddenly are able to delegate rights that we don't have?

Not everyone who is opposed to welfare programs is against helping the poor 
in other ways. Your implication that none of the people who are against 
welfare want to help the poor is demonstrably false, because there are 
plenty of examples of people who are against welfare, but who do help the 
poor in other ways.

As I already explained in my previous post, we wouldn't need every single 
person who is currently paying into welfare to pay into charity in order 
for it to be as efficient. This is because more of the money that goes into 
charity actually goes to the people that need it. About 70% of the money 
that goes into private charities gets to the people who need it, where as 
only about 30% of the money that goes into government welfare programs gets 
to the people who need it. Here is a source: 
http://mises.org/journals/jls/21_2/21_2_1.pdf

So, even if only half of the money that currently goes into welfare went 
into private charities instead, the poor would actually receive more money, 
because 70% of 50 is more than 30% of 100.

And just to clear up the apparent misunderstanding, I don't mean that 30% 
of the overall amount that everyone pays in taxes goes to the poor. I mean 
that only 30% of the part of your taxes that goes into welfare actually 
ends up going to the poor.

In a free society, if someone voluntarily agrees to take a job like mining 
for diamonds, it must necessarily be because they would be better off 
taking that job than whatever the alternative would be. Otherwise, why 
would they agree to take that job?

There isn't anything inherently wrong with drug dealing or prostitution. If 
someone wants to do those things, they should be free to do them. If people 
who don't really want to do those things are pressured into doing them due 
to economic situations, this is because the government has taken away their 
other options. By placing price controls on labor, the government has made 
it more difficult for people who are less productive to find work. By 
artificially increasing the cost of living through taxation and inflation, 
the government has made it even more difficult for those who are able to 
find work to make a living wage. The government also artificially increases 
the value of drugs and prostitution by enforcing prohibition laws. If 
something is prohibited, it becomes harder to get, and is therefore more 
valuable. For all these reasons, many poor people end up turning to things 
like drug dealing and prostitution.

People tend to take much better care of private property than they do of 
unowned property or public property. The way to best protect and preserve 
the environment would be to privatize as much land as possible.

Private prisons have nothing to do with the free market. They are 
contracted by the government, allowed to have government enforced 
monopolies, and lock people up who have violated government made and 
enforced laws.

Slavery also had nothing to do with the free market. Slavery was funded and 
enforced by the government. The government made it illegal for slaves to 
escape from their masters. If a slave escaped, the government would use tax 
payer money to have that slave caught and returned to his or her master. 
Slave owners wouldn't have been able to enforce slavery on their own. In 
Brazil, slavery actually ended because the government stopped funding it, 
and the slave owners couldn't afford to go after their slaves who escaped. 
As soon as the slaves realized this, they all just took off and there was 
nothing their masters could do about it.

Do I even need to explain why the military industrial complex has nothing 
to do with the free market? The only way that anyone can profit off of war 
is if people are forced to pay for it by the government.

It's getting exhausting having to type out these long posts, and I can't 
possibly address every single one of the 50 billion things you blamed the 
free market for. I tried to address as many of them as I could. What I 
would like to get back to is my question about how we're able to delegate 
rights that we don't have to the government. That's the thing I'm most 
interested in hearing you respond to.
comments.author: Joseph F

in fact I only see the exact opposite, so I'll stick with paying taxes, 
thanks.
